CLERKS NOTICE REGARDING CHANGE OF LOCATION FOR JUDGE GILLIAM:Effective March 2, 2017, Judge Haywood S. Gilliam, Jr.'s courtroom and chambers will be located in the Ronald V. Dellums Federal Building and United States Courthouse, Courtroom 2, 4th Floor, 1301 Clay Street, Oakland, CA 94612. On or after March 2, 2017, all filings for matters pending on Judge Gilliam's docket, all court appearances, and all deliveries of chambers copies of documents must be made at the Oakland Courthouse. The days and times for law and motion calendars and all currently scheduled proceedings remain unchanged.Please note that all of Judge Gilliam's case files will be moved to the Oakland Courthouse; therefore, all case numbers assigned to him will be changed slightly to reflect the correct location. Previously, all case numbers started with 3 to indicate the San Francisco office (Example: 3:15-cv-1129-HSG). As of March 2, 2017 all of Judge Gilliam's case files will begin with 4 to indicate the Oakland office, but everything else will stay the same (Example: 4:15-cv-1129-HSG). When e-filing, using the short case number format will always avoid problems when searching for the correct case: 12-12345 (YY-NNNNN).For information on the Oakland Courthouse please go to: http://cand.uscourts.gov/locations-oakland (mclS, COURT STAFF) (Filed on 3/1/2017) (Entered: 03/01/2017)

case_data.plaintiff_description: Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), a non-profit organization concerned with technology-related civil liberty issues.
case_data.summary:
On April 19, 2016, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a non-profit organization concerned with technology-related civil liberty issues, filed suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against the United States Department of Justice under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. §552. The case was assigned to Judge Haywood S. Gilliam, Jr.

It was public knowledge that the government had attempted to compel third parties to assist in surveillance activities, such as when the FBI publicly demanded court orders requiring Apple to create a backdoor to the iPhone. The Electronic Frontier Foundation sought to learn about the government’s efforts to obtain non-public court orders. The Foundation had filed a Freedom of Information Act request on March 7, 2016, seeking documents pertaining to requests for the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to compel third parties to provide access to their customers’ encrypted communications or to provide other technical assistance in gaining access to private communications. When the Justice Department withheld the requested documents, the Foundation filed this lawsuit for an injunction requiring the Department to produce all such documents created between 1978 and June 1, 2015.

In the fall of 2016, both parties moved for summary judgment. While these motions were pending, the Justice Department worked to process the original Freedom of Information Act request. A year later, after the parties acknowledged that the scope of their dispute would not be known until the document production process was complete, the court denied both summary judgment motions as moot on September 29, 2017.

On September 25, 2017, January 31, 2018, and August 22, 2018, the Justice Department released a total of 73 documents, out of 79 identified as responsive to the Foundation’s request. The Department claimed that the remaining six documents, opinions written by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, were classified and exempt from disclosure.

Both parties filed new motions for partial summary judgment in the fall of 2018. The Foundation argued that the Justice Department could not legally withhold the remaining documents: although the six documents were exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act, they were also subject to Section 402 of the USA FREEDOM Act, which required the declassification of certain opinions of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court.

On March 26, 2019, the court granted summary judgment in favor of the Justice Department. 376 F.Supp.3d 1023. Although Section 402 might require the government to declassify the opinions, that statute created no private right of action to enforce the requirement. The court found that it would be inappropriate to use the Freedom of Information Act to enforce Section 402, and therefore declined to even address whether Section 402 actually required the government to declassify the opinions. It found that the Justice Department had provided sufficiently detailed factual information to support its exemption claims, and that the Foundation had failed to overcome the presumption of good faith to which the Department was entitled.

On April 5, 2019, the parties filed a joint status report, notifying the court that aside from attorneys’ fees, no dispute remained to be resolved. The parties submitted a proposed judgment in favor of the Justice Department as to its responses to the Foundations’s requests. They also requested that the court order the parties to provide a status report, due by May 9, 2019, regarding their efforts to resolve the dispute over attorneys’ fees and costs.

Upon receipt of the status report on May 10, 2019, the court extended the deadline for notifying the court of the status of the parties’ efforts to finalize the agreement concerning attorneys’ fees and costs to June 10, 2019.

On June 10, 2019, the parties submitted a joint status report indicating that the parties finalized their agreement concerning attorneys’ fees and costs and have signed a settlement agreement. The parties jointly agreed to dismiss the case on July 3, 2019.
case_data.summary_short: In 2016, a civil liberties non-profit filed this freedom of information act (FOIA) complaint in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. Plaintiff sought injunctive relief for for the release of any documents relating to DOJ applications to the FISC requesting third parties to provide access to encrypted communications or to provide other types of technical assistance to access private communications. On September 25, 2017, January 31, 2018, and August 22, 2018, the DOJ released a total of seventy-three out of seventy-nine documents it had identified as being responsive to EFFโs FOIA request. The DOJ contended that the remaining six documents were exempted from disclosure under FOIA exemptions. On March 26, 2019, Judge Gilliam granted the DOJโs motion for partial summary judgment and denied the EFFโs cross motion. On April 5, 2019, the parties filed a joint status report, notifying the court that, outside of attorneyโs fees, no dispute remained to be resolved.
case_data.summary_tiny: Federal lawsuit forces Department of Justice to disclose information on government efforts to compel private companies to assist in government surveillance. @EFF (N.D. Cal.)

21  II.  SUMMARY JUDGMENT STANDARD 
22  Summary judgment is proper when a โmovant shows that there is no genuine dispute as to 
23  any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a).  
24  A fact is โmaterialโ if it โmight affect the outcome of the suit under the governing law.โ  Anderson 
25  v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 248 (1986).  A dispute is โgenuineโ if there is evidence in the 
26  record sufficient for a reasonable trier of fact to decide in favor of the nonmoving party.  Id.  The 
27  Court views the inferences reasonably drawn from the materials in the record in the light most 
28  favorable to the nonmoving party, Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp., 475 U.S. 
2

3  Schriro, 514 F.3d 878, 884โ85 (9th Cir. 2008).  If a court finds that there is no genuine dispute of 
4  material fact as to only a single claim or defense or as to part of a claim or defense, it may enter 
5  partial summary judgment.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(a).

7  burden of persuasion and the initial burden of producing those portions of the pleadings, 
8  discovery, and affidavits that show the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.  Celotex Corp.

documents.text:
Case 4:16-cv-02041-HSG   Document 1   Filed 04/19/16   Page 1 of 8
 
MARK RUMOLD (SBN 279060) 
1 
mark@eff.org 
NATHAN D. CARDOZO (SBN 259097) 
2 
nate@eff.org 
AARON MACKEY (SBN 286647) 
3 
amackey@eff.org 
ELECTRONIC FRONTIER FOUNDATION   
4 
815 Eddy Street 
San Francisco, CA 94109 
5 
Telephone: (415) 436-9333 
Facsimile: (415) 436-9993 
6 
 
   
7 
Attorneys for Plaintiff    
ELECTRONIC FRONTIER FOUNDATION 
8 
 
 
9 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
10 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
11 
SAN FRANCISCO DIVISION 
12 
ELECTRONIC FRONTIER FOUNDATION,  )   
) 
13 
) 
    Plaintiff,  COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE 
) 
14  RELIEF FOR VIOLATION OF THE 
) 
  v.  FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT,  
) 
15 
5 U.S.C. ยง 552 
) 
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT  
) 
16 
  OF JUSTICE,    
) 
) 
17 
    Defendant.  ) 
) 
18 
19 
1.  This is an action under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. ยง 552, for 
20 
injunctive and other appropriate relief.  Plaintiff seeks the release of records that Plaintiff requested 
21 
from Defendant United States Department of Justice (DOJ) concerning applications to the Federal 
22 
Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) and the courtโs significant opinions and orders.  
23 
PARTIES 
24 
2.  Plaintiff  Electronic  Frontier  Foundation  (EFF)  is  a  not-for-profit  corporation 
 
25 
established under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, with offices in San Francisco, 
26 
California and Washington, D.C.  EFF is a donor-supported membership organization that works to 
27 
inform policymakers and the general public about civil liberties issues related to technology and to 
28 
    -1-   
  COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR VIOLATION OF   
  THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552 
 
 

 
 
Case 4:16-cv-02041-HSG   Document 1   Filed 04/19/16   Page 2 of 8
 
1 
act as a defender of those liberties.  In support of its mission, EFF uses the FOIA to obtain and 
2 
disseminate information concerning the activities of federal agencies.    
3 
3.  Defendant  DOJ  is  an  agency  of  the  Executive  Branch  of  the  United  States 
4 
Government. DOJ is an โagencyโ within the meaning of 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(f). 
5 
JURISDICTION  
6 
4.  This  Court  has  both  subject  matter  jurisdiction  over  this  action  and  personal 
7 
jurisdiction over the parties pursuant to 5 U.S.C. ยงยง 552(a)(4)(B) and 552(a)(6)(C)(i).  This Court 
8 
also has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1331.   
9 
VENUE AND INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT 
10 
5.  Venue  is  proper  in  this  district  under  5  U.S.C.  ยง  552(a)(4)(B)  and  28  U.S.C. 
11 
ยง 1391(e). 
12 
6.  Assignment to the San Francisco division is proper pursuant to Local Rule 3-2(c) and 
13 
(d) because a substantial portion of the events giving rise to this action occurred in this district and 
14 
division, where Plaintiff is headquartered. 
15 
FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS  
16 
 
The USA Freedom Act Requires Surveillance Court Transparency  
17 
7.  The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (FISC) reviews applications from the 
18 
government concerning national security surveillance. Since its creation in the 1970s, the FISCโs 
19 
role has gradually expanded. Where the court focused initially on granting applications to conduct 
20 
surveillance  on  particular  targets,  it  is  now  increasingly  asked  to  decide  the  legality,  and 
21 
constitutionality, of entire programs of government surveillance.  
22 
8.  In the past, the FISC typically considered government applications ex parte, and its 
23 
opinions and orders were, almost without exception, classified. Appellate rulings on the FISCโs 
24 
decisions by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review (FISCR) are similarly classified. 
 
25 
As the effect of the FISC and FISCRโs decisions expanded, the ex parte and classified nature of their 
26 
opinions proved increasingly problematic: the public was prevented from understanding how these 
27 
federal courts were interpreting surveillance laws and the Constitution, often in ways that implicated 
28 
    -2-   
  COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR VIOLATION OF   
  THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552 
 
 

 
 
Case 4:16-cv-02041-HSG   Document 1   Filed 04/19/16   Page 3 of 8
 
1 
citizensโ rights.  
2 
9.  After  the  terrorist  attacks  of  September  11,  2001,  the  FISC  and  FISCR  were 
3 
increasingly called upon to decide significant or novel questions of federal or constitutional lawโin 
4 
secret. This resulted in the creation of a vast body of secret federal surveillance law.  
5 
10.  The tension between our democratic traditions of openness and access to the courts 
6 
and the growing body of secret surveillance law culminated in the Guardian newspaper disclosing a 
7 
then-classified order of the FISC in June 2013. The disclosure touched off a years-long debate about 
8 
the nature, scope, and propriety of our nationโs national security surveillance laws.   
9 
11.  That debate spurred the passage, in June 2015, of the USA FREEDOM Act, Pub. L. 
10 
114-23, 129 Stat. 268 (June 2, 2015) (โUSA Freedomโ), which implemented a series of national 
11 
security surveillance reforms. 
12 
12.  One  aspect  of  USA  Freedomโs  reforms  included  the  required  declassification  of 
13 
โsignificantโ FISC and FISCR decisions. Specifically, Section 402(a) of USA Freedom states that: 
14  the  Director  of  National  Intelligence,  in  consultation  with  the  Attorney 
General, shall conduct a declassification review of each decision, order, or 
15  opinion issued by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court or the Foreign 
Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review (as defined in section 601(e)) 
  16  that includes a significant construction or interpretation of any provision of 
law, including any novel or significant construction or interpretation of the 
17  term  โspecific  selection  termโ,  and,  consistent  with  that  review,  make 
publicly  available  to  the  greatest  extent  practicable  each  such  decision, 
18  order, or opinion. 
19  13.  Both before and since enactment of the USA Freedom, Plaintiff EFF has endeavored 
20  to inform the public about the FISCโs role in national security surveillance by requesting, through 
21  FOIA, certain FISC opinions and orders. 
22  U.S. Government Seeks Court Orders to Compel Access to Encrypted Communications  
23  14.  As the public debated national security surveillance reform, the government quietly 
24  began  increasing  pressure  on  companies  to  provide  access  to  encrypted  communications  or  to 
 
25  provide other types of technical assistance to access private communications. 
26  15.  For example, one news report indicated that the government had considered taking 
27  Apple, Inc. (โApple") to court after the Department of Justice obtained a court order requiring the 
28  company to provide real-time access to its customersโ encrypted iMessages. Apple represented it 
    -3-   
  COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR VIOLATION OF   
  THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552 
 
 

 
 
Case 4:16-cv-02041-HSG   Document 1   Filed 04/19/16   Page 4 of 8
 
1 
was  unable  to  comply  with  an  order  it  had  received  because  it  could  not  decrypt  the 
2 
communications. Matt Apuzzo, David E. Sanger, and Michael S. Schmidt, Apple and Other Tech 
3 
Companies Tangle With U.S. Over Data Access, The New York Times (Sept. 7, 2015). 
4 
16.  Then, in February, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) obtained a court order 
5 
requiring Apple to write software and digitally sign it so that the FBI could defeat built-in security 
6 
measures on an iPhone. Apple contested the order. Eric Lichtblau & Katie Benner, Apple Fights 
7 
Order to Unlock San Bernardino Gunmanโs iPhone, The New York Times (Feb. 17, 2016). 
8 
17.  Although the examples described in Paragraphs 16 and 17 occurred in traditional 
9 
federal courts, the FISC also has jurisdiction to consider compelled technical assistance. The Foreign 
10 
Intelligence Surveillance Act (โFISAโ), 50 U.S.C. ch. 36, allows the government to seek technical 
11 
assistance from third parties with respect to any application it seeks or order or opinion it receives 
12 
from the FISC. See, e.g., 50 U.S.C. ยง 1805(c)(2)(B).  
13 
18.  News outlets have reported that the government has sought FISC orders and opinions 
14 
that required private companies to turn over their source code so that the government can identify 
15 
and  exploit  vulnerabilities  for  its  own  surveillance  purposes.  Zack  Whittaker,  US  Government 
16 
  Pushed Tech Firms to Hand Over Source Code, ZDNet (March 17, 2016).  
17 
19.  Plaintiff EFF seeks to inform the public about the extent to which the government has 
18 
used  FISA  and  the  FISC  to  compel  private  companies  into  providing  assistance  that  would 
19 
undermine the safety and security of millions of people who rely on software and the devices that 
20 
run them, such as the iPhone, every day. 
21 
Plaintiffโs FOIA Requests 
22 
Plaintiffโs FOIA for FISC orders requiring technical assistance of third parties 
23 
20.  In a letter dated October 8, 2015, Plaintiff filed a FOIA request with the National 
24 
Security Division of Defendant DOJ (Oct. 8 FOIA). The request sought: 
 
25 
โข Any applications to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court (โFISCโ) 
that included requests for technical assistance under the Foreign Intelligence 
26 
Surveillance Act (โFISAโ), 50 U.S.C. ch. 36. 
 
27 
โข Any written FISC opinions or orders regarding any applications submitted 
to the court that included requests for technical assistance under FISA.  
28 
    -4-   
  COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR VIOLATION OF   
  THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552 
 
 

 
 
Case 4:16-cv-02041-HSG   Document 1   Filed 04/19/16   Page 5 of 8
 
 
1 
โข Any related briefing or correspondence with the FISC, its staff, or any 
third  party  (including  but  not  limited  to  Apple,  Inc.  and  its  attorneys) 
2 
concerning applications submitted to the court that included requests for 
technical assistance under FISA. 
3 
21.  In the Oct. 8 FOIA, Plaintiff also sought expedited processing of its request as well as 
4 
the media fee waiver and public interest fee waiver.  
5 
22.  On November 23, 2015, Defendant acknowledged Plaintiffโs Oct. 8 FOIA request via 
6 
e-mail and granted its requests for expedited processing and fee waivers.  
7 
23.  On December 16, 2015, Defendant provided its final response to the Oct. 8 FOIA via 
8 
letter. In DOJโs final response, Defendant stated โwe understand your request to be limited to 
9 
applications,  orders,  and  related  briefs  and  correspondence  specifically  concerning  requests  for 
10 
technical assistance ordering the decryption of, or assistance in decrypting, encrypted electronic 
11 
communications.โ  
12 
24.  Defendant further stated:  
13 
We have processed your request and identified no responsive applications 
14  to the FISC. Relatedly, we have also not identified any FISC opinions, FISC 
orders, or briefing regarding such applications. We have identified two 
15  items of potentially responsive correspondence. We have determined that 
both of these records are exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of 
  16  Information Act pursuant to 5 U.S.C. 552 (b)(1). 
17  25.  On January 22, 2016, Plaintiff filed an administrative appeal of Defendantโs final 
18  response via mail and Defendantโs online FOIA portal. Plaintiff appealed on grounds that Defendant 
19  had failed to conduct an adequate search for records responsive to its Oct. 8 FOIA request and that 
20  Defendant had improperly withheld records under FOIA. Plaintiff sought expedited processing of its 
21  administrative appeal. 
22  26.  On February 1, 2016, Defendant acknowledged receipt of Plaintiffโs administrative 
23  appeal via email.  
24  27.  On February 11, 2016, Defendant sent Plaintiff a second acknowledgement of its 
 
25  administrative appeal via email. In that correspondence, Defendant granted Plaintiffโs request for 
26  expedited processing of the administrative appeal. 
27 
28 
    -5-   
  COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR VIOLATION OF   
  THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552 
 
 

 
 
Case 4:16-cv-02041-HSG   Document 1   Filed 04/19/16   Page 6 of 8
 
1 
28.  On April 4, 2016, Defendant denied Plaintiffโs administrative appeal via a letter that 
2 
stated it was โaffirming, on partly modified grounds,โ the agencyโs initial denial of Plaintiffโs Oct. 8 
3 
FOIA. 
4 
29.   In denying the administrative appeal of Plaintiffโs Oct. 8 FOIA, Defendant stated that 
5 
if Plaintiff was โdissatisfied with my action on your appeal, the FOIA permits you to file a lawsuit in 
6 
federal district court in accordance with 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(B).โ Thus, Plaintiff has exhausted all 
7 
applicable administrative remedies. 
8 
30.  Defendant continues to wrongfully withhold the requested records from Plaintiff. 
9 
Plaintiffโs FOIA request for significant or novel FISC opinions and orders 
10 
31.  In a letter dated March 7, 2016, Plaintiff filed another FOIA request with the National 
11 
Security Division of the DOJ (March 7 FOIA). The request sought: 
12  โข  Any  โdecision,  order,  or  opinion  issued  by  the  Foreign  Intelligence 
Surveillance Court or the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review 
13  (as defined in section 601(e)),โ issued from 1978 to June 1, 2015, โthat 
includes a significant construction or interpretation of any provision of law, 
14  including any novel or significant construction or interpretation of the term 
โspecific selection term.โโ USA FREEDOM Act, Pub. L. 114-23, ยง 402(a) 
15  (2015), codified at 50 U.S.C. ยง 1872(a). 
 
16  โข  Any  โdecision,  order,  or  opinion  issued  by  the  Foreign  Intelligence 
 
Surveillance Court or the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review 
17  (as defined in section 601(e)),โ issued from June 2, 2015 to present, โthat 
includes a significant construction or interpretation of any provision of law, 
18  including any novel or significant construction or interpretation of the term 
โspecific selection term.โโ USA FREEDOM Act, Pub. L. 114-23, ยง 402(a) 
19  (2015), codified at 50 U.S.C. ยง 1872(a). 
20  32.  Plaintiffโs March 7 FOIA request also sought the media fee waiver and public interest 
21  fee waiver.  
22  33.  By letter dated March 14, 2016, Defendant acknowledged receipt of Plaintiffโs March 
23  7 FOIA request. 
24  34.    On March 25, 2016, the parties discussed ways Defendant could prioritize its review 
 
25  of FISC opinions responsive to Plaintiffโs second request. By email on April 5, 2016, Plaintiff 
26  provided various suggestions for prioritization of opinions and orders that should be declassified and 
27  released.  
28 
    -6-   
  COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR VIOLATION OF   
  THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552 
 
 

 
 
Case 4:16-cv-02041-HSG   Document 1   Filed 04/19/16   Page 7 of 8
 
1 
35.  As of the date of the filing of this Complaint, Defendant has failed to respond 
2 
substantively to Plaintiffโs March 7 FOIA request. 
3 
36.  As the statutory time period by which Defendant must respond to Plaintiffโs March 7 
4 
FOIA request has passed, Plaintiff has exhausted all applicable administrative remedies. 
5 
37.  Defendant continues to wrongfully withhold the requested records from Plaintiff. 
6 
CAUSES OF ACTION 
7 
Violation of the Freedom of Information Act for Wrongful Withholding of Agency Records 
8 
38.  Plaintiff repeats and realleges paragraphs 1-37.   
9 
39.  Defendant has wrongfully withheld agency records requested by Plaintiff by failing to 
10 
conduct an adequate search for records responsive to Plaintiffโs request, by failing to produce all 
11 
records in the agencyโs possession responsive to Plaintiffโs request, and by failing to adequately 
12 
segregate responsive from non-responsive records. 
13 
40.  Plaintiff  has  exhausted  applicable  administrative  remedies  with  respect  to 
14 
Defendantโs wrongful withholding of the requested records. 
15 
41.  Plaintiff is entitled to injunctive relief with respect to the release and disclosure of the 
16 
  requested documents. 
17 
REQUESTED RELIEF 
18 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiff prays that this Court: 
19 
42.  order Defendant and its components to process immediately the requested records in 
20 
their entirety; 
21 
43.  order Defendant to disclose the requested records in their entirety and make copies 
22 
available to Plaintiff; 
23 
44.  order Defendant to waive all fees associated with the processing and release of the 
24 
requested records; 
 
25 
45.  provide for expeditious proceedings in this action 
26 
46.  award Plaintiff its costs and reasonable attorneys fees incurred in this action; and 
27 
47.  grant such other relief as the Court may deem just and proper. 
28 
    -7-   
  COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF FOR VIOLATION OF   
  THE FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552 
 
 

 
 
Case 4:16-cv-02041-HSG   Document 1   Filed 04/19/16   Page 8 of 8
